prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sub-kpc imaging of a bright quasar host galaxy at z=6.5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution (0.12") imaging of the source P036+03 at z=6.5, in which the PdBI detected a very bright [CII] line with a flux of 5.2 Jy km/s (published in Banados et al. 2015). The resolution of the previous PdBI observations was ~2.0", and here we ask for 0.12" imaging (corresponding to 0.7 kpc). Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although the line width of the [CII] emission in the quasar host has a FWHM of 360 km/s, we want to measure possible deviations from ordered motion, such as outflow features. These could be much narrower than the bulk motion of the gas in the quasar host.
Also, we will search the immediate surroundings of the quasar for accompanying galaxies in [CII], since the quasar host could be located in a high density environment, or undergoing a merger. Galaxies at those redshifts can have much narrower [CII] line widths, so in order to accurately measure narrower lines, we request a frequency resolution of ~5 km/s. Note that this corresponds to a spectral averaging of 8, which already significantly reduces the data rate.

The size of [CII] emission line regions at lower redshift quasar hosts are found to be in the range 1.5-4 kpc (e.g. Walter et al. 2009; Wang et al. 2013). To resolve this emission, we require a minimal resolution of 0.7 kpc, or ~0.12" at this redshift. Since the source is unresolved in our PdBI observations, we can set an upper limit to the size of ~1.6", although it is likely that the largest scales will be below 1" (~5.5 kpc at z=6.5).

The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging of the source P036+03 at z=6.5, in which the PdBI detected a very bright [CII] line with a flux of 5.2 Jy km/s and a FWHM of 360 km/s, and the underlying continuum with a flux density of 2.5 mJy (published in Banados et al. 2015).
The spatial resolution of our PdBI observations was 2.2x1.6 arcsec^2 and the source was not resolved. With the requested observations we aim to resolve this bright [CII] emission. Lower redshift studies found that the sizes of [CII] emitting regions in quasar hosts are in the range 1.5-4 kpc. To resolve this emission we need to reach a resolution of 0.7 kpc. At these redshifts this corresponds to ~0.12". Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible, as confirmed by our extensive simulations (e.g. see Fig. 4). This is also consistent with the following calculation, where we spread the total flux over the expected number of resolution elements:
If we assume that the (unknown) size of the [CII] emission is 3x3 kpc, then that corresponds to 0.55x0.55 arcsec^2, or a source area of ~0.3 arcsec^2. With a resolution of ~0.12", this emission is resolved into 20 beams. Since the emission line is Gaussian, we can approximate the peak line flux density with the formula: line flux = line peak x FWHM, or line peak = line flux / FWHM. The peak line flux is therefore 5.2 Jy km/s / 360 km/s = 14.44 mJy. If the emission is uniformly spread over the 20 beams, then the peak flux density per 0.12" beam is 0.72 mJy. To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we require to measure this peak flux density at a S/N>~4. With this requirement, we are still able to measure the motion of the gas in case the source is more extended than assumed, or if the flux density is lower in the outer regions.
To reach an rms of 0.72/4=0.18 mJy over 1/3 of the FWHM of the line (=120 km/s), we required an on-source integration time of 38.5 minutes, or 1.14 hours including the calibration overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sub-kpc imaging of a bright quasar host galaxy at z=6.6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution (0.12") imaging of the source J0305-3150 at z=6.6. With ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a very bright [CII] line with a strength of 3.6 Jy km/s (published in Venemans et al. 2015b). The resolution of the previous ALMA observations was ~0.7", and here we ask for 0.12" imaging (corresponding to 0.7 kpc). Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although the line width of the [CII] emission in the quasar host has a FWHM of 225 km/s, we want to measure possible deviations from ordered motion, such as outflow features. These could be much narrower than the bulk motion of the gas in the quasar host.
Also, we will search the immediate surroundings of the quasar for accompanying galaxies in [CII], since the quasar host could be located in a high density environment, or undergoing a merger. Galaxies at those redshifts can have much narrower [CII] line widths, so in order to accurately measure narrower lines, we request a frequency resolution of ~5 km/s. Note that this corresponds to a spectral averaging of 8, which already significantly reduces the data rate.

To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we have shown in Fig. 3 that we require a spatial resolution of 0.7 kpc, or ~1.2". The largets angular scale is set by the size of the [CII] emitting region in our low resolution ALMA Cycle 1 data (<0.8").

The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging of the source J0305-3150 at z=6.6. In ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a bright [CII] line with a strength of 3.6 Jy km/s and a line FWHM of 225 km/s, and the underlying continuum with a flux density of 3.7 mJy (published in Venemans et al. 2015b).
Our ALMA Cycle 1 data were taken at low spatial resolution (~0.6"-0.7", or 3-4 kpc at these high redshifts), and we only barely resolved the [CII] emission. With the requested resolution of 0.12" kpc (0.7 kpc at z=6.6) our aim is to constrain the size of the gas and dust emission. Given the brightness of the source, imaging the bright [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible, as confirmed by our extensive simulations (e.g. see Fig. 4). This is also consistent with the following calculation, where we spread the total flux over the expected number of resolution elements:
We can estimate the size of the [CII] emission region from our ALMA Cycle 1 data. The size is approximately 0.61x0.39 arcsec^2 = 0.24 arcsec^2 (Venemans et al. 2015b). With the requested spatial resolution, we will resolve this source into ~17 beams. Since the emission line is Gaussian, we can approximate the peak line flux density with the formula: line flux = line peak x FWHM, or line peak = line flux / FWHM. The peak line flux is therefore 3.6 Jy km/s / 225 km/s = 16 mJy. If this emission is spread uniformly over the 17 beams, then the peak flux density per beam is 16/17 = 0.94 mJy. To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we require to measure this peak flux density at a S/N>~4. With this requirement, we are still able to measure the motion of the gas in case the source is more extended than assumed, or if the flux density is lower in the outer regions.
To reach an rms of 0.94/4=0.235 mJy over 1/3 of the FWHM of the emission line (=75 km/s), we request 38 minutes of on-source integration time and a total request for this source including calibrations of 1.14 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sub-kpc imaging of a bright quasar host galaxy at z=6.8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution (0.12") imaging of the source J0109-3047 at z=6.8. With ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a bright [CII] line with a strength of 2.4 Jy km/s (published in Venemans et al. 2015b). The resolution of the previous ALMA observations was ~0.7", and here we ask for 0.12" imaging (corresponding to 0.7 kpc). Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although the line width of the [CII] emission in the quasar host has a FWHM of 330 km/s, we want to measure possible deviations from ordered motion, such as outflow features. These could be much narrower than the bulk motion of the gas in the quasar host.
Also, we will search the immediate surroundings of the quasar for accompanying galaxies in [CII], since the quasar host could be located in a high density environment, or undergoing a merger. Galaxies at those redshifts can have much narrower [CII] line widths, so in order to accurately measure narrower lines, we request a frequency resolution of ~5 km/s. Note that this corresponds to a spectral averaging of 8, which already significantly reduces the data rate.

To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we have shown in Fig. 3 that we require a spatial resolution of 0.7 kpc, or ~1.2". The largets angular scale is set by the size of the [CII] emitting region in our low resolution ALMA Cycle 1 data (<0.8").

The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging of the source J0109-3047 at z=6.8. With ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a bright [CII] line with a strength of 2.4 Jy km/s and a line FWHM of 330 km/s, and the underlying continuum with a flux density of 0.62 mJy (published in Venemans et al. 2015b).
Our ALMA Cycle 1 data were taken at low spatial resolution (~0.6"-0.7", or 3-4 kpc at these high redshifts), and we only barely resolved the [CII] emission. With the requested resolution of 0.12" (0.7 kpc at z=6.8) our aim is to constrain the size of the gas and dust emission. Given the brightness of the source, imaging the bright [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible, as confirmed by our extensive simulations (e.g. see Fig. 4). This is also consistent with the following calculation, where we spread the total flux over the expected number of resolution elements:
We can estimate a rough size of the [CII] emitting region from our ALMA Cycle 1 data. The size is approximately 0.41x0.35 arcsec^2 = 0.144 arcsec^2 (with large error bars, see Venemans et al. 2015b). With the requested spatial resolution of 0.12", we will resolve this source into ~9 beams. Since the emission line is Gaussian, we can approximate the peak line flux density with the formula: line flux = line peak x FWHM, or line peak = line flux / FWHM. The peak line flux is therefore 2.4 Jy km/s / 330 km/s = 7.27 mJy. If this emission is spread uniformly over the 9 beams, then the peak flux density per beam is 7.27/9 = 0.81 mJy. To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we require to measure this peak flux density at a S/N>~4. With this requirement, we are still able to measure the motion of the gas in case the source is more extended than assumed, or if the flux density is lower in the outer regions.
To reach an rms of 0.81/4=0.202 mJy over 1/3 of the FWHM of the emission line (=110 km/s), we request 33 minutes of on-source integration time and a total request for this source including calibrations of 1.04 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sub-kpc imaging of a bright quasar host galaxy at z=6.9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution (0.13") imaging of the source J2348-3054 at z=6.9. In ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a bright [CII] line with a strength of 1.93 Jy km/s (published in Venemans et al. 2015b). The resolution of the previous ALMA observations was ~0.7", and here we ask for 0.13" imaging (corresponding to 0.7 kpc). Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although the line width of the [CII] emission in the quasar host has a FWHM of 450 km/s, we want to measure possible deviations from ordered motion, such as outflow features. These could be much narrower than the bulk motion of the gas in the quasar host.
Also, we will search the immediate surroundings of the quasar for accompanying galaxies in [CII], since the quasar host could be located in a high density environment, or undergoing a merger. Galaxies at those redshifts can have much narrower [CII] line widths, so in order to accurately measure narrower lines, we request a frequency resolution of ~5 km/s. Note that this corresponds to a spectral averaging of 8, which already significantly reduces the data rate.

From our low resolution ALMA Cycle 1 data, we can only infer an upper limit on the size of the quasar host galaxy of <4 kpc, consistent withtThe size of [CII] emission line regions at lower redshift quasar hosts that are found to be in the range 1.5-4 kpc (e.g. Walter et al. 2009; Wang et al. 2013). To resolve this emission, we require a minimal resolution of 0.7 kpc, or ~0.13" at this redshift. The largets angular scale is set by the size of the [CII] emitting region in our low resolution ALMA Cycle 1 data (<0.8").

The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging of the source J2348-3054 at z=6.9. With ALMA in Cycle 1 we already detected (in ~10 minutes on-source) a bright [CII] line with a strength of 1.93 Jy km/s and a line FWHM of 450 km/s, and the underlying continuum with a flux density of 2.0 mJy (published in Venemans et al. 2015b).
Our ALMA Cycle 1 data were taken at low spatial resolution (~0.6"-0.7", or 3-4 kpc), and we do not resolve the [CII] emission. Lower redshift studies found that the sizes of [CII] emitting regions in quasar hosts are in the range 1.5-4 kpc. With the requested resolution of 0.13" (corresponding to 0.7 kpc at z=6.9) our aim is to resolve the [CII] emission and to constrain the size of the gas and dust emission. Given the brightness of the source, imaging the bright [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible, as confirmed by our extensive simulations (e.g. see Fig. 4). This is also consistent with the following calculation, where we spread the total flux over the expected number of resolution elements:
Since the line flux of J2348-3054 is very similar to that of J0109-3047, we here assume the size of the line emitting region is roughly similar to that of J0109-3047 (0.144 arcsec^2). As for the other sources we request a spatial resolution of 0.7 kpc, which corresponds to 0.13" at z=6.9. We would therefore resolve a source with an area of 0.144 arcsec^2 into ~8 beams. Since the emission line is Gaussian, we can approximate the peak line flux density with the formula: line flux = line peak x FWHM, or line peak = line flux / FWHM. The peak line flux is therefore 1.93 Jy km/s / 450 km/s = 4.3 mJy. If this emission is spread uniformly over the 8 beams, then the peak flux density per beam is 4.3/8 = 0.54 mJy. To accurately measure the rotation of the gas and to look for deviations from coherent motion (e.g. outflows), we require to measure this peak flux density at a S/N>~4. With this requirement, we are still able to measure the motion of the gas in case the source is more extended than assumed, or if the flux density is lower in the outer regions.
To reach an rms of 0.54/4=0.135 mJy over 1/3 of the FWHM of the emission line (=150 km/s), we request 52 minutes of on-source integration time and a total request for this source including calibrations of 1.77 hours.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sub-kpc imaging of a bright quasar host galaxy at z=7.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging (0.13") of the source J1120+0641 at z=7.1, our highest redshift [CII] detection. With the PdBI we already detected the [CII] line with a strength of 1.0 Jy km/s (published in Venemans et al. 2012). The resolution of the previous PdBI observations was ~2.0", and here we ask for 0.13" imaging (corresponding to 0.7 kpc). Given the brightness of the sources, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although the line width of the [CII] emission in the quasar host has a FWHM of 360 km/s, we want to measure possible deviations from ordered motion, such as outflow features. These could be much narrower than the bulk motion of the gas in the quasar host.
Also, we will search the immediate surroundings of the quasar for accompanying galaxies in [CII], since the quasar host could be located in a high density environment, or undergoing a merger. Galaxies at those redshifts can have much narrower [CII] line widths, so in order to accurately measure narrower lines, we request a frequency resolution of ~5 km/s. Note that this corresponds to a spectral averaging of 8, which already significantly reduces the data rate.

The size of [CII] emission line regions at lower redshift quasar hosts are found to be in the range 1.5-4 kpc (e.g. Walter et al. 2009; Wang et al. 2013). To resolve this emission, we require a minimal resolution of 0.7 kpc, or ~0.13" at this redshift. Since the source is unresolved in our PdBI observations, we can set an upper limit to the size of ~1.7", although it is likely that the largest scales will be below 1" (~5.3 kpc at z=7.1).

The goal of this proposal is to resolve the bright [CII] emission in z>6.5 quasar hosts detected in our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI programmes. In this Science Goal, we ask for high resolution imaging of the source J1120+0641 at z=7.1, our highest redshift [CII] detection. With the PdBI we already detected the [CII] line with a strength of 1.0 Jy km/s and a FWHM of 235 km/s, and the underlying continuum with a flux density of 0.61 mJy (published in Venemans et al. 2012).
The spatial resolution of our PdBI observations was 2.0x1.7 arcsec^2 and the source was not resolved. With the requested observations we aim to resolve this bright [CII] emission. Lower redshift studies found that the sizes of [CII] emitting regions in quasar hosts are in the range 1.5-4 kpc. To resolve this emission we need to reach a resolution of 0.7 kpc. At these redshifts this corresponds to ~0.13". Given the brightness of the source, imaging the [CII] and underlying continuum is imminently possible, as confirmed by our extensive simulations (e.g. see Fig. 4). This is also consistent with the following calculation, where we spread the total flux over the expected number of resolution elements:
Since we do not know the size of the [CII] emission (yet), we here assume it has the same extent (0.144 arcsec^2) as that of J0109-3047 at z=6.8. With a requested spatial resolution of 0.13", we will resolve this emission into ~8 beams. Since the emission line is Gaussian, we can approximate the peak line flux density with the formula: line flux = line peak x FWHM, or line peak = line flux / FWHM. The peak line flux is therefore 1.0 Jy km/s / 235 km/s = 4.4 mJy. If the emission is uniformly spread over the 8 beams, then the peak flux density per 0.13" beam is 0.55 mJy. If we want to measure this peak flux density with a S/N ~3, then we need to obtain an rms of 0.183 mJy.
To reach an rms of 0.183 mJy over 1/3 of the FWHM of the line (~80 km/s), we require an on-source integration time of 59.5 minutes, or 1.89 hours including the calibration overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High redshift quasars are likely hosted by massive and luminous galaxies in the early universe. Recently we discovered several bright quasars at 6.5<z<7.1, providing a unique opportunity to study the physical properties of massive galaxies at z~7. Our ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI data of 5 of these sources already revealed strong [CII] emission and far-infrared (FIR) continua. These are the only objects currently known at z>6.5 with bright [CII] emission. Here we propose to obtain followup observations of this small sample at sub-kpc resolution (0.7 kpc or ~0.12") to, for the first time, address key aspects that cannot be answered with the available data: Utilising the unique capabilities of ALMA, we will be able to (1) constrain the morphology and kinematics of the emission line gas, (2) produce a map of the star formation as traced by the FIR, (3) look for possible recent merger events, (4) search for infall/outflow signatures and (5) derive a well-constrained dynamical mass. Observations of this small sample will thus greatly enhance our knowledge of and provide first statistics on the properties of the earliest massive galaxies when the universe was only ~800 Myr old.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
